thread.title: Matthew Dellavedova 'always wanted' to stay with Cavs
thread.title_full: Matthew Dellavedova 'always wanted' to stay with Cavs

author: customerservice@sportingnews.com (Sporting News)
title: Matthew Dellavedova 'always wanted' to stay with Cavs
text:
Matthew Dellavedova 'always wanted' to stay with Cavs Sporting News 13 hrs ago customerservice@sportingnews.com (Sporting News) © Gregory Shamus/Getty Images Matthew Dellavedova #8 of the Cleveland Cavaliers drives against Jeff Teague #0 of the Atlanta Hawks in the fourth quarter during Game Three of the Eastern Conference Finals of the 2015 NBA Playoffs at Quicken Loans Arena on May 24, 2015 in Cleveland. Guard Matthew Dellavedova always wanted to re-sign with the Cleveland Cavaliers despite the lure of free agency.
AdChoices The 25-year-old Australian, who emerged as an unlikely hero during the NBA Finals, re-signed with the Cavs in July on what was reportedly a one-year deal. He said Cleveland was where he wanted to be after coming so close to helping the Cavs to their first NBA championship.
MORE: Every NBA team's greatest strength for the 2015-16 season
"The business side of basketball and the NBA is a crazy thing. Free agency isn’t something that I was too familiar with," he wrote for NBA Australia . "I was always wanted to come back to Cleveland because I love playing here, I’ve made a lot of good friends on the team, and I feel comfortable living here.
"To come so close to winning last season, it made me realise how awesome it would be to bring a championship to these fans in Cleveland."
The Cavs open their regular-season campaign against the Chicago Bulls at the United Center on Tuesday. Dellavedova and his team head into that clash on the back of a 1-6 pre-season, but that run is of no concern.
"We're not worried about our pre-season losses," Dellavedova wrote. There have been so many players coming in and out through injury and rest which makes it hard to get a gauge as to where the team is at. ...
"Hopefully we can kick off the new season on a roll, and get off to a better start than last season."
